Chapter 223, Section 2.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 218, Section 3, and Chapter 223, Section 2.

Sullivan v. Brookline Housing Authority,.raw_text: Sullivan v. Brookline Housing Authority, 442 Mass. 514 (2004).
Sullivan v. Brookline Housing Authority,.proposition: The actions and inactions of Plaintiff constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
Sullivan v. Brookline Housing Authority,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the constitutionality of a municipal rate-of-development zoning bylaw and does not analyze or apply the elements of negligence under Massachusetts law, nor does it evaluate any plaintiff’s conduct as negligent. Its focus is on zoning powers, due process, and public welfare, not tort liability. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority that a plaintiff’s actions or inactions constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
Sullivan v. Brookline Housing Authority,.relevant_excerpt: “The classic recitation of the constitutional test is whether a zoning bylaw is ‘clearly arbitrary and unreasonable, having no substantial relation to the public health, safety, morals, or general welfare.’ Euclid v. Ambler Realty Co., 272 U.S. 365, 395 (1926). … More specifically, due process requires that a zoning bylaw bear a rational relation to a legitimate zoning purpose.”

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2001).
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: The actions and inactions of Plaintiff constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns alleged negligence by the defendant supermarket, not negligence by the plaintiff. The court analyzes premises liability, notice, and adopts the mode-of-operation doctrine, ultimately reversing summary judgment against the plaintiff. Nowhere does the court find or discuss that the plaintiff’s own actions or inactions constitute negligence under Massachusetts law; comparative or contributory negligence of the plaintiff is not at issue in the holding.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: "For the foregoing reasons, we conclude that summary judgment was improperly granted and, given our adoption of the mode of operation approach, the defendant had notice of the inherent risks associated with its chosen mode of operation. We vacate the judge’s decision granting summary judgment in favor of the defendant and remand the case to the Superior Court for further proceedings consistent with this opinion."

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (2008)..proposition: The actions and inactions of Plaintiff constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (2008)..support_reasoning: The excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurring opinion discussing the proper standard of care owed by occupiers of land and criticizing the continued use of status-based classifications (licensee/invitee/trespasser). It does not address whether a particular plaintiff’s actions or inactions constitute negligence, nor does it establish a rule that the plaintiff’s conduct in any circumstance is negligent under Massachusetts law. Therefore, it does not support the proposition that the actions and inactions of Plaintiff constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (2008)..relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

Shultz v. Honey Dew Donuts, Inc., 457 Ma.raw_text: Shultz v. Honey Dew Donuts, Inc., 457 Mass. 529 (2008).
Shultz v. Honey Dew Donuts, Inc., 457 Ma.proposition: The actions and inactions of Plaintiff constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
Shultz v. Honey Dew Donuts, Inc., 457 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion in Shultz v. Honey Dew Donuts, Inc. does not concern tort liability, the elements of negligence, or whether a plaintiff’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law. Instead, it addresses standing of a crime victim/witness to seek interlocutory review and sets procedural and accommodation guidelines for disabled witnesses in criminal cases. It therefore provides no authority on whether a plaintiff’s actions or inactions amount to negligence and does not support the stated proposition.
Shultz v. Honey Dew Donuts, Inc., 457 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "McDonough acknowledges that as an alleged victim of a crime, she has no legally cognizable interest in the prosecution of the defendant that would permit her to seek review of the judge’s order... Rather, McDonough claims, she seeks to vindicate a violation of her own substantive right to ‘give evidence’... Whatever the scope of the obligation on a State court under the ADA to provide reasonable accommodation to a witness who is disabled in order to permit her to ‘participat[e] in’ judicial proceedings... McDonough may not herself seek interlocutory appellate review..."

Poulin v. Atlantic Coast Enterprises, In.raw_text: Poulin v. Atlantic Coast Enterprises, Inc., 399 Mass. 682 (2017).
Poulin v. Atlantic Coast Enterprises, In.proposition: The actions and inactions of Plaintiff constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
Poulin v. Atlantic Coast Enterprises, In.support_reasoning: The case is a criminal prosecution for statutory rape and indecent assault and battery, focusing on evidentiary issues (spontaneous utterance hearsay, scope of cross-examination) and jury instructions on intent. It does not involve a civil negligence claim, does not analyze the elements of negligence under Massachusetts law, and does not evaluate any plaintiff’s conduct as negligent. Therefore it cannot support the proposition that the plaintiff’s actions and inactions constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
Poulin v. Atlantic Coast Enterprises, In.relevant_excerpt: The defendant argues that the judge’s instructions on intent were inadequate. At trial, the defendant acknowledged that the touching which formed the basis of the indictment for indecent assault and battery had occurred. He maintained, however, that it was accidental, unintended, and uninvited by him. We note that this argument is refuted by the defendant’s signed statement, “I did have [her] put her mouth on my penis while we were in the bathroom.”

Davis v. Star Market Co., 384 Mass. 88 (.proposition: The actions and inactions of Plaintiff constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
Davis v. Star Market Co., 384 Mass. 88 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is a disciplinary decision concerning judicial misconduct and bar discipline of Judge McKenney; it does not involve a tort action, a private plaintiff, or any analysis of a plaintiff’s negligence under Massachusetts law. The court’s reasoning is focused on judicial ethics, sanctions, and mitigating factors, not on elements of negligence or comparative fault. Accordingly, this case cannot be cited as authority that a plaintiff’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law.
Davis v. Star Market Co., 384 Mass. 88 (.relevant_excerpt: "Regrettably, the instant proceedings require us once again to consider the appropriate sanction to be imposed upon a judge for misconduct in office... Nevertheless, the retirement or resignation of a judge accused of misconduct in office does not terminate our author[ity] or responsibility to consider imposition of further sanctions relative to his continuing status as a member of the bar."

Kacavas v. Harbach Electronics Corporati.proposition: The actions and inactions of Plaintiff constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
Kacavas v. Harbach Electronics Corporati.support_reasoning: The cited opinion is a federal criminal case from the Fifth Circuit addressing liability under 18 U.S.C. § 924(c), not a civil negligence action under Massachusetts law. It does not analyze elements of negligence, Massachusetts tort standards, or plaintiffs’ conduct in a negligence context. Therefore it cannot be used as authority that the plaintiff’s actions or inactions constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
Kacavas v. Harbach Electronics Corporati.relevant_excerpt: “Wainuskis moved to set aside her conviction and sentence for the violation of § 924(c)(1), based on a change in the law resulting from the clarification of ‘use’ of a firearm in Bailey v. United States… The district court… found that there was sufficient information to support Wainuskis’s guilty plea and conviction and denied her motion.”

Stewart v. Robertson, 177 Mass. 1 (1900).proposition: The actions and inactions of Plaintiff constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
Stewart v. Robertson, 177 Mass. 1 (1900).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns contract rights of an assignee, the existence and timing of a contract, and whether an assignee can recover on a quantum meruit when the assignor voluntarily fails to complete performance. It does not analyze or decide whether the plaintiff’s conduct constitutes negligence, nor does it discuss negligence standards under Massachusetts law. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority that the plaintiff’s actions or inactions amount to negligence.
Stewart v. Robertson, 177 Mass. 1 (1900).relevant_excerpt: “When, on July 20, Lancaster notified the defendant that he would ‘have to give the job up,’ the plaintiff, as his assignee, had no right to recover for the work done between July 15 and July 20; Lancaster could not recover on the contract, for he failed to perform the work which he had agreed to perform during the month ending August 15; nor on a quantum meruit, for one who has voluntarily failed to perform his contract cannot recover on a quantum meruit for the part performed by him.”

Brown v. Northeastern Univ., 463 Mass. 5.support_reasoning: This is a Massachusetts criminal case involving murder, assault, evidentiary rulings, jury selection, prosecutorial argument, self‑defense/defense of another, and ineffective assistance. It does not address the elements of civil negligence, standards for plaintiff negligence, or any tort liability analysis. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that the plaintiff’s actions or inactions constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
Brown v. Northeastern Univ., 463 Mass. 5.relevant_excerpt: The defendant was convicted by a Superior Court jury of murder in the first degree in the shooting death of Nabil Essaid, armed assault with intent to kill Ahmed Obbada and Mohemmed Lebdoui, assault with a dangerous weapon on Boston municipal police Officer Matthew Clark, and various firearms offenses... Having carefully reviewed the entire record pursuant to our duty under G. L. c. 278, § 33E, we discern no reason to reduce the murder verdict or to order a new trial.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 458 Mass. 614 (2020)..proposition: The actions and inactions of Plaintiff constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 458 Mass. 614 (2020)..support_reasoning: The opinion in Mounsey v. Ellard addresses the authority of a Massachusetts Superior Court judge to review and modify pretrial conditions of release imposed by a District Court judge under G. L. c. 276, § 58A. It does not discuss, define, or apply the elements of negligence, nor does it evaluate any party’s conduct under Massachusetts negligence law. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that the plaintiff’s actions or inactions constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 458 Mass. 614 (2020)..relevant_excerpt: "In the present case, here on a reservation and report by a single justice of this court, we consider whether a Superior Court judge has the authority to review and modify pretrial conditions of release imposed on a defendant by a District Court judge pursuant to G. L. c. 276, § 58A. For the reasons that follow, we conclude that a Superior Court judge does have such authority."
